'''Ernie Lancaster''' (born 1953)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mylife.com/ernie-lancaster |title=Ernie Lancaster - Mount Dora, Florida |publisher=Mylife.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[blues rock]] guitarist and songwriter.  He has released two solo albums since 1991. Lancaster has the ability to vary his style between strict blues, and [[rock music|rock]], [[jazz]], [[soul music|soul]] and [[pop music|pop]].<ref name="AMG"/>

He has cited his influences as [[Roy Buchanan]], [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] and [[John Lee Hooker]].<ref name="Orlando">{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-11-24/entertainment/9111220476_1_lancaster-ernestly-creepers|title=Ernie Lancaster Plays The Blues By Feel|author=Parry Gettelman|date=November 24, 1991|accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Lancaster was born in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]]. He later grew up in [[South Carolina]] before relocating with his family to [[Mount Dora, Florida]].  He formed his own band while at school, which eventually played at [[Stetson University]] and on television in [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]].  After dropping out of college, and getting married at age 19,<ref name="Ernie">{{cite web|url=http://www.ernielancaster.com/ernie.htm|title=Ernie Lancaster: Official Website|publisher=Ernielancaster.com|accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref> 
he was a founding member of the Sex Change Band in the mid-1970s.<ref name="Orlando"/> As the backing outfit for [[Root Boy Slim]],<ref name="AMG"/> the band was a fixture in the [[Mid-Atlantic states|mid-Atlantic]] blues and rock scene, and favored a mix of Memphis-style boogie rock/blues.<ref>{{cite web| last=Thien  | first=Carl |date = June 2003| accessdate=2012-12-04|work=Gullbuy.com New Sound Review|url=http://gullbuy.com/buy/2003/6_3/rootboyslim.cfm | title=Root Boy Slim & the Sex Change Band}}</ref> They recorded an album for [[Warner Bros. Records]] in 1978, their first of six records.<ref name="Ernie"/> In 1989, Lancaster played on the ''Pee Wee, Fred and Maceo'' album recorded by [[The J.B.'s|the JB Horns]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= Wesley
| last= Fred
| year= 2002
| title= Hit Me, Fred: Recollections of a Sideman
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Duke University Press]] 
| location= [[Durham, North Carolina]]
| isbn= 0-8223-2909-3
| page= 287}}</ref>

Lancaster's guitar work appeared on numerous albums in the 1980s and 1990s, before he released his debut solo album.  That was ''Ernestly'', an all [[instrumental]] affair, which was released on [[Ichiban Records]] in 1991.<ref name="AMG"/> Other musicians Lancaster supplied guitar playing for included [[Rufus Thomas]],<ref name="Album">{{cite web|last=Henderson |first=Alex |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/ernestly-mw0000275051 |title=Ernestly - Ernie Lancaster : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref> [[Reverend Billy C. Wirtz]], [[Kenny Neal]], [[Noble "Thin Man" Watts|Noble Watts]] and [[Lucky Peterson]].  The latter musician was heavily involved in playing the [[Hammond organ]] on Lancaster's first album, with a co-starring credit noted on the album's sleeve.<ref name="AMG"/>  The [[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Alex Henderson, noted that "Although not stunning, ''Ernestly'' provides some gritty and unpretentious fun."<ref name="Album"/>

Lancaster's second album, ''Lightnin' Alley'', which comprised self composed tracks (in a similar vein to his first album) was issued in May 2008.<ref name="AMG"/>  He has appeared at the [[Boundary Waters Blues Festival]].
